🚧 How I Overcame a Major Project Failure 🎤A few years ago, I was leading the deployment of a Node.js application to AWS Lightsail. Everything looked great on paper — the code was solid, the pipeline was configured, and the deadline was tight, but doable.Then came the failure.Right after deployment, the application didn't serve as expected. I could SSH into the server, the services were running, but users kept seeing a blank page. Logs showed no clear errors. We had to halt the rollout, and stakeholders were understandably frustrated.The problem? The app was starting from the wrong entry point — we had deployed index.ts, but our CI/CD pipeline defaulted to the wrong directory (/var/www/html). It was a classic case of “it worked on my machine” — and it cost us valuable time.💡 What I Learned:Never assume environment consistency. Document and test deployment directories explicitly.Automate sanity checks post-deployment (even a simple curl to the home page could’ve flagged this earlier).Own the failure, but focus on the fix. I worked late into the night with my team, rewrote the pipeline, and redeployed from the correct entry point.Most importantly, I learned to communicate transparently with stakeholders during a crisis.Today, our deployments are smoother, and I’ve grown more confident handling surprises in production.🗣️ Have you ever had a project crash and burn, only to bounce back stronger? Let’s talk — your comeback story might inspire someone today.hashtag#TechLeadership hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CICD hashtag#FailureToSuccess hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#AWS hashtag#Lightsail hashtag#Nodejs hashtag#Reflection

RCIP - Timmins, ON has released their list of designated employers. Let the hashtag#HungerGames begin!

I’m now firmly in my third month of un(der)employment. It’s been an interesting one.👨🏼‍💻 Good News: I began working a FT job recently which is in a completely different world than where I came from, but in many ways not that different at all. It’s enough money to keep me off the state’s dime but just barely. It’s a shadow of my most recent salary and the first time I’ve had to actually punch a clock in (uuuugh) 30 years or more BUT it’s a job and in lieu of a world that seems more likely to cut off its nose to spite its face than do anything that makes sense at all, I’ll take it. This is something I should have done the last time I was out of work. Idle hands, and all that.🎉 It shortens the resume gap, and if any of my potential future employers are reading this hopefully they’ll see that I am willing to do anything it takes to get the job done. Even if that job is just making the grocery budget manageable.⛔️ DO NOT let your pride or ego get in your way. Take that random PT or FT gig while you’re still seeking your next main gig. Get out of the house. Enjoy the process. You never know what might happen.☑️ Worst case - it’s another hard reset and I make something cool out of this. I’ll add some new tools to my arsenal, meet some genuinely awesome people, and not be bored in the interim. Wouldn’t be the first time…🙏🏻 That’s how I got into live events, after all.🚨 This job is also being super considerate about letting me take short-term event contracts as they come along, too. It’s a win-win, really.🥺 A lot of people I know continue to get laid off/made redundant/get Trumped. I hate it. Good people. Smart people. I am pulling for you all to land as close to what you want or need as you can. I am trying to share as many of your hashtag#OpenToWork posts as possible to help. Reach back if your new gig has a head count. 😉

Why I Have Declined a Fully-Remote $7,150 Net/Month Offer.Recently, I was actively job hunting and got pretty far with a promising opportunity. I completed the technical task, passed the interviews, and received an offer from a well-known international company with a strong media presence and a quite ethical business model.The position was for a DevOps engineer. The terms were excellent: official B2B contract, fully remote work - I could work from anywhere, even a small village back home in Kazakhstan. They offered a three-week paid company bootcamp in Cyprus and a long-term collaboration. Some of their employees had been with the company for over 12 years - it sounded like a dream job.I had already arranged an early exit from my current work, started looking for tickets to Cyprus, and was mentally ready to sign the contract.But when the actual contract arrived, although it was generally fine, one detail immediately caught my attention: there was no liability limitation clause.For employees under standard labor law in almost any country, it is usually not an issue because labor laws protect employees against unlimited financial liability. But for B2B or contractor agreements, things are different - unless explicitly stated otherwise, the contractor can be held fully liable.As someone with significant DevOps experience, I know firsthand that mistakes can be costly. It might only take a few hours to accidentally cause damages worth several months of my salary. While I’ve never had a serious incident myself, I understand that no one is immune to risk - it’s part of the job.So, I politely asked to add a simple clause: to cap the liability to a maximum of three months' salary.The HR representative immediately refused, saying, "This is our standard contract. Everyone signs it, and so should you." They told me they’ve never had any lawsuits and insisted there was no need to change anything. Moreover, I was repeatedly told that literally no one in the whole company, including legal, HR, and the hiring manager, understands my concern and I should just sign the contract as it is. The hiring manager allegedly is also under the same contract, has caused damages ranging into hundreds of thousands of USD before, and "everything was fine."I spent a lot of time carefully explaining my concern - that it’s not about mistrust but about basic risk management - but they stuck to their position. Eventually, they gave me an ultimatum: sign it as-is, or walk away.I chose to walk away.I've been in this industry long enough to know: mistakes will happen eventually, and when they do, they can be very expensive. Signing a contract with unlimited personal liability would be like playing Russian roulette with my financial future. In my opinion it just wasn't worth it.

My Friday thought for today! “Hiring Indigenous talent isn’t just about being inclusive—it’s about empowering the future of work."As an Indigenous woman, I’ve often felt the weight of walking into interviews wondering if I’d be seen, heard, or truly considered. When I applied to Clear Seas I was nervous. I didn’t think I’d get the job—I didn’t tick every single box on the job posting.  But here I am 5 years later, loving and always learning in my role as Director of Indigenous Programs. Too often, Indigenous professionals are overlooked. Told we’re not “qualified” enough. Told we don’t quite “fit.” But here’s what I want to say to every employer out there: Indigenous people are more than survivors of colonization and residential schools—we are leaders.We bring with us generations of knowledge, a spirit of adaptability, and an openness to learning and growth. We are connectors. Listeners. Innovators. And when we apply for roles in your organization, we’re not just looking for a job—we’re offering *you* a chance to work *with us.*So, yes—hire Indigenous professionals. Not just because it’s good for reconciliation, or because it checks a box. Do it because we’re powerful. We’re forward-thinking. hashtag#IndigenousCareers hashtag#ReconciliationInAction hashtag#ICPP hashtag#OceanSector hashtag#IndigenousExcellence hashtag#ClearSeas hashtag#RepresentationMatters

Think fast and get in touch, before *poof* it’s gone! What are you waiting for? Opportunity’s a fairy, flying fast - catch her! 🫵🏾

🚧 How I Overcame a Major Project Failure 🎤A few years ago, I was leading the deployment of a Node.js application to AWS Lightsail. Everything looked great on paper — the code was solid, the pipeline was configured, and the deadline was tight, but doable.Then came the failure.Right after deployment, the application didn't serve as expected. I could SSH into the server, the services were running, but users kept seeing a blank page. Logs showed no clear errors. We had to halt the rollout, and stakeholders were understandably frustrated.The problem? The app was starting from the wrong entry point — we had deployed index.ts, but our CI/CD pipeline defaulted to the wrong directory (/var/www/html). It was a classic case of “it worked on my machine” — and it cost us valuable time.💡 What I Learned:Never assume environment consistency. Document and test deployment directories explicitly.Automate sanity checks post-deployment (even a simple curl to the home page could’ve flagged this earlier).Own the failure, but focus on the fix. I worked late into the night with my team, rewrote the pipeline, and redeployed from the correct entry point.Most importantly, I learned to communicate transparently with stakeholders during a crisis.Today, our deployments are smoother, and I’ve grown more confident handling surprises in production.🗣️ Have you ever had a project crash and burn, only to bounce back stronger? Let’s talk — your comeback story might inspire someone today.hashtag#TechLeadership hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CICD hashtag#FailureToSuccess hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#AWS hashtag#Lightsail hashtag#Nodejs hashtag#Reflection

I’m now firmly in my third month of un(der)employment. It’s been an interesting one.👨🏼‍💻 Good News: I began working a FT job recently which is in a completely different world than where I came from, but in many ways not that different at all. It’s enough money to keep me off the state’s dime but just barely. It’s a shadow of my most recent salary and the first time I’ve had to actually punch a clock in (uuuugh) 30 years or more BUT it’s a job and in lieu of a world that seems more likely to cut off its nose to spite its face than do anything that makes sense at all, I’ll take it. This is something I should have done the last time I was out of work. Idle hands, and all that.🎉 It shortens the resume gap, and if any of my potential future employers are reading this hopefully they’ll see that I am willing to do anything it takes to get the job done. Even if that job is just making the grocery budget manageable.⛔️ DO NOT let your pride or ego get in your way. Take that random PT or FT gig while you’re still seeking your next main gig. Get out of the house. Enjoy the process. You never know what might happen.☑️ Worst case - it’s another hard reset and I make something cool out of this. I’ll add some new tools to my arsenal, meet some genuinely awesome people, and not be bored in the interim. Wouldn’t be the first time…🙏🏻 That’s how I got into live events, after all.🚨 This job is also being super considerate about letting me take short-term event contracts as they come along, too. It’s a win-win, really.🥺 A lot of people I know continue to get laid off/made redundant/get Trumped. I hate it. Good people. Smart people. I am pulling for you all to land as close to what you want or need as you can. I am trying to share as many of your hashtag#OpenToWork posts as possible to help. Reach back if your new gig has a head count. 😉

💼 Staying Motivated During the Job Search JourneyJob searching as a Finance professional can feel like running a marathon without a finish line in sight. Some days bring exciting opportunities and great conversations. Other days? Silence.What keeps me motivated is remembering the value we bring.  💯 Finance isn't just about numbers,  It's about 👉 helping drive strategy.👉 Enabling growth.👉 Shaping the future of businesses.Every application, every interview, and every networking conversation is an investment, not just in landing the next role, but in becoming a stronger, more resilient version of myself.To all my fellow Finance professionals navigating the search:🌟 Stay focused on your goals.🌟 Celebrate small wins (even just sending that one application today).🌟 Keep sharpening your skills and growing your network.🌟 Believe in the expertise and impact you bring.The right opportunity will come, and when it does, you'll be ready.💥 If you're on a similar journey, I'd love to connect and encourage each other along the way! 🚀hashtag#FinanceCareers hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#FPandA hashtag#FinanceLeadership hashtag#Resilience hashtag#GrowthMindset

Why I Have Declined a Fully-Remote $7,150 Net/Month Offer.Recently, I was actively job hunting and got pretty far with a promising opportunity. I completed the technical task, passed the interviews, and received an offer from a well-known international company with a strong media presence and a quite ethical business model.The position was for a DevOps engineer. The terms were excellent: official B2B contract, fully remote work - I could work from anywhere, even a small village back home in Kazakhstan. They offered a three-week paid company bootcamp in Cyprus and a long-term collaboration. Some of their employees had been with the company for over 12 years - it sounded like a dream job.I had already arranged an early exit from my current work, started looking for tickets to Cyprus, and was mentally ready to sign the contract.But when the actual contract arrived, although it was generally fine, one detail immediately caught my attention: there was no liability limitation clause.For employees under standard labor law in almost any country, it is usually not an issue because labor laws protect employees against unlimited financial liability. But for B2B or contractor agreements, things are different - unless explicitly stated otherwise, the contractor can be held fully liable.As someone with significant DevOps experience, I know firsthand that mistakes can be costly. It might only take a few hours to accidentally cause damages worth several months of my salary. While I’ve never had a serious incident myself, I understand that no one is immune to risk - it’s part of the job.So, I politely asked to add a simple clause: to cap the liability to a maximum of three months' salary.The HR representative immediately refused, saying, "This is our standard contract. Everyone signs it, and so should you." They told me they’ve never had any lawsuits and insisted there was no need to change anything. Moreover, I was repeatedly told that literally no one in the whole company, including legal, HR, and the hiring manager, understands my concern and I should just sign the contract as it is. The hiring manager allegedly is also under the same contract, has caused damages ranging into hundreds of thousands of USD before, and "everything was fine."I spent a lot of time carefully explaining my concern - that it’s not about mistrust but about basic risk management - but they stuck to their position. Eventually, they gave me an ultimatum: sign it as-is, or walk away.I chose to walk away.I've been in this industry long enough to know: mistakes will happen eventually, and when they do, they can be very expensive. Signing a contract with unlimited personal liability would be like playing Russian roulette with my financial future. In my opinion it just wasn't worth it.

My Friday thought for today! “Hiring Indigenous talent isn’t just about being inclusive—it’s about empowering the future of work."As an Indigenous woman, I’ve often felt the weight of walking into interviews wondering if I’d be seen, heard, or truly considered. When I applied to Clear Seas I was nervous. I didn’t think I’d get the job—I didn’t tick every single box on the job posting.  But here I am 5 years later, loving and always learning in my role as Director of Indigenous Programs. Too often, Indigenous professionals are overlooked. Told we’re not “qualified” enough. Told we don’t quite “fit.” But here’s what I want to say to every employer out there: Indigenous people are more than survivors of colonization and residential schools—we are leaders.We bring with us generations of knowledge, a spirit of adaptability, and an openness to learning and growth. We are connectors. Listeners. Innovators. And when we apply for roles in your organization, we’re not just looking for a job—we’re offering *you* a chance to work *with us.*So, yes—hire Indigenous professionals. Not just because it’s good for reconciliation, or because it checks a box. Do it because we’re powerful. We’re forward-thinking. hashtag#IndigenousCareers hashtag#ReconciliationInAction hashtag#ICPP hashtag#OceanSector hashtag#IndigenousExcellence hashtag#ClearSeas hashtag#RepresentationMatters

🚧 How I Overcame a Major Project Failure 🎤A few years ago, I was leading the deployment of a Node.js application to AWS Lightsail. Everything looked great on paper — the code was solid, the pipeline was configured, and the deadline was tight, but doable.Then came the failure.Right after deployment, the application didn't serve as expected. I could SSH into the server, the services were running, but users kept seeing a blank page. Logs showed no clear errors. We had to halt the rollout, and stakeholders were understandably frustrated.The problem? The app was starting from the wrong entry point — we had deployed index.ts, but our CI/CD pipeline defaulted to the wrong directory (/var/www/html). It was a classic case of “it worked on my machine” — and it cost us valuable time.💡 What I Learned:Never assume environment consistency. Document and test deployment directories explicitly.Automate sanity checks post-deployment (even a simple curl to the home page could’ve flagged this earlier).Own the failure, but focus on the fix. I worked late into the night with my team, rewrote the pipeline, and redeployed from the correct entry point.Most importantly, I learned to communicate transparently with stakeholders during a crisis.Today, our deployments are smoother, and I’ve grown more confident handling surprises in production.🗣️ Have you ever had a project crash and burn, only to bounce back stronger? Let’s talk — your comeback story might inspire someone today.hashtag#TechLeadership hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CICD hashtag#FailureToSuccess hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#AWS hashtag#Lightsail hashtag#Nodejs hashtag#Reflection

I’m now firmly in my third month of un(der)employment. It’s been an interesting one.👨🏼‍💻 Good News: I began working a FT job recently which is in a completely different world than where I came from, but in many ways not that different at all. It’s enough money to keep me off the state’s dime but just barely. It’s a shadow of my most recent salary and the first time I’ve had to actually punch a clock in (uuuugh) 30 years or more BUT it’s a job and in lieu of a world that seems more likely to cut off its nose to spite its face than do anything that makes sense at all, I’ll take it. This is something I should have done the last time I was out of work. Idle hands, and all that.🎉 It shortens the resume gap, and if any of my potential future employers are reading this hopefully they’ll see that I am willing to do anything it takes to get the job done. Even if that job is just making the grocery budget manageable.⛔️ DO NOT let your pride or ego get in your way. Take that random PT or FT gig while you’re still seeking your next main gig. Get out of the house. Enjoy the process. You never know what might happen.☑️ Worst case - it’s another hard reset and I make something cool out of this. I’ll add some new tools to my arsenal, meet some genuinely awesome people, and not be bored in the interim. Wouldn’t be the first time…🙏🏻 That’s how I got into live events, after all.🚨 This job is also being super considerate about letting me take short-term event contracts as they come along, too. It’s a win-win, really.🥺 A lot of people I know continue to get laid off/made redundant/get Trumped. I hate it. Good people. Smart people. I am pulling for you all to land as close to what you want or need as you can. I am trying to share as many of your hashtag#OpenToWork posts as possible to help. Reach back if your new gig has a head count. 😉

Why I Have Declined a Fully-Remote $7,150 Net/Month Offer.Recently, I was actively job hunting and got pretty far with a promising opportunity. I completed the technical task, passed the interviews, and received an offer from a well-known international company with a strong media presence and a quite ethical business model.The position was for a DevOps engineer. The terms were excellent: official B2B contract, fully remote work - I could work from anywhere, even a small village back home in Kazakhstan. They offered a three-week paid company bootcamp in Cyprus and a long-term collaboration. Some of their employees had been with the company for over 12 years - it sounded like a dream job.I had already arranged an early exit from my current work, started looking for tickets to Cyprus, and was mentally ready to sign the contract.But when the actual contract arrived, although it was generally fine, one detail immediately caught my attention: there was no liability limitation clause.For employees under standard labor law in almost any country, it is usually not an issue because labor laws protect employees against unlimited financial liability. But for B2B or contractor agreements, things are different - unless explicitly stated otherwise, the contractor can be held fully liable.As someone with significant DevOps experience, I know firsthand that mistakes can be costly. It might only take a few hours to accidentally cause damages worth several months of my salary. While I’ve never had a serious incident myself, I understand that no one is immune to risk - it’s part of the job.So, I politely asked to add a simple clause: to cap the liability to a maximum of three months' salary.The HR representative immediately refused, saying, "This is our standard contract. Everyone signs it, and so should you." They told me they’ve never had any lawsuits and insisted there was no need to change anything. Moreover, I was repeatedly told that literally no one in the whole company, including legal, HR, and the hiring manager, understands my concern and I should just sign the contract as it is. The hiring manager allegedly is also under the same contract, has caused damages ranging into hundreds of thousands of USD before, and "everything was fine."I spent a lot of time carefully explaining my concern - that it’s not about mistrust but about basic risk management - but they stuck to their position. Eventually, they gave me an ultimatum: sign it as-is, or walk away.I chose to walk away.I've been in this industry long enough to know: mistakes will happen eventually, and when they do, they can be very expensive. Signing a contract with unlimited personal liability would be like playing Russian roulette with my financial future. In my opinion it just wasn't worth it.

My Friday thought for today! “Hiring Indigenous talent isn’t just about being inclusive—it’s about empowering the future of work."As an Indigenous woman, I’ve often felt the weight of walking into interviews wondering if I’d be seen, heard, or truly considered. When I applied to Clear Seas I was nervous. I didn’t think I’d get the job—I didn’t tick every single box on the job posting.  But here I am 5 years later, loving and always learning in my role as Director of Indigenous Programs. Too often, Indigenous professionals are overlooked. Told we’re not “qualified” enough. Told we don’t quite “fit.” But here’s what I want to say to every employer out there: Indigenous people are more than survivors of colonization and residential schools—we are leaders.We bring with us generations of knowledge, a spirit of adaptability, and an openness to learning and growth. We are connectors. Listeners. Innovators. And when we apply for roles in your organization, we’re not just looking for a job—we’re offering *you* a chance to work *with us.*So, yes—hire Indigenous professionals. Not just because it’s good for reconciliation, or because it checks a box. Do it because we’re powerful. We’re forward-thinking. hashtag#IndigenousCareers hashtag#ReconciliationInAction hashtag#ICPP hashtag#OceanSector hashtag#IndigenousExcellence hashtag#ClearSeas hashtag#RepresentationMatters

🚧 How I Overcame a Major Project Failure 🎤A few years ago, I was leading the deployment of a Node.js application to AWS Lightsail. Everything looked great on paper — the code was solid, the pipeline was configured, and the deadline was tight, but doable.Then came the failure.Right after deployment, the application didn't serve as expected. I could SSH into the server, the services were running, but users kept seeing a blank page. Logs showed no clear errors. We had to halt the rollout, and stakeholders were understandably frustrated.The problem? The app was starting from the wrong entry point — we had deployed index.ts, but our CI/CD pipeline defaulted to the wrong directory (/var/www/html). It was a classic case of “it worked on my machine” — and it cost us valuable time.💡 What I Learned:Never assume environment consistency. Document and test deployment directories explicitly.Automate sanity checks post-deployment (even a simple curl to the home page could’ve flagged this earlier).Own the failure, but focus on the fix. I worked late into the night with my team, rewrote the pipeline, and redeployed from the correct entry point.Most importantly, I learned to communicate transparently with stakeholders during a crisis.Today, our deployments are smoother, and I’ve grown more confident handling surprises in production.🗣️ Have you ever had a project crash and burn, only to bounce back stronger? Let’s talk — your comeback story might inspire someone today.hashtag#TechLeadership hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CICD hashtag#FailureToSuccess hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#AWS hashtag#Lightsail hashtag#Nodejs hashtag#Reflection

RCIP - Timmins, ON has released their list of designated employers. Let the hashtag#HungerGames begin!

I’m now firmly in my third month of un(der)employment. It’s been an interesting one.👨🏼‍💻 Good News: I began working a FT job recently which is in a completely different world than where I came from, but in many ways not that different at all. It’s enough money to keep me off the state’s dime but just barely. It’s a shadow of my most recent salary and the first time I’ve had to actually punch a clock in (uuuugh) 30 years or more BUT it’s a job and in lieu of a world that seems more likely to cut off its nose to spite its face than do anything that makes sense at all, I’ll take it. This is something I should have done the last time I was out of work. Idle hands, and all that.🎉 It shortens the resume gap, and if any of my potential future employers are reading this hopefully they’ll see that I am willing to do anything it takes to get the job done. Even if that job is just making the grocery budget manageable.⛔️ DO NOT let your pride or ego get in your way. Take that random PT or FT gig while you’re still seeking your next main gig. Get out of the house. Enjoy the process. You never know what might happen.☑️ Worst case - it’s another hard reset and I make something cool out of this. I’ll add some new tools to my arsenal, meet some genuinely awesome people, and not be bored in the interim. Wouldn’t be the first time…🙏🏻 That’s how I got into live events, after all.🚨 This job is also being super considerate about letting me take short-term event contracts as they come along, too. It’s a win-win, really.🥺 A lot of people I know continue to get laid off/made redundant/get Trumped. I hate it. Good people. Smart people. I am pulling for you all to land as close to what you want or need as you can. I am trying to share as many of your hashtag#OpenToWork posts as possible to help. Reach back if your new gig has a head count. 😉

IT/ Software Applications Manager Oceanside, CA (San Diego Metro) 135-160k+ DOE    About Us:   We are a growing leading manufacturer and supplier of premium consumer products for the automobile industry. We are seeking a dynamic IT Development Manager to lead our data, infrastructure, and software engineering team and drive the integration and optimization of our critical business systems.   Job Summary:   We are looking for an experienced IT Development Manager with exceptional communication and leadership skills to oversee the planning, execution, and success of our software development and integration projects. The ideal candidate will have a strong background in managing enterprise applications, particularly ERP, WMS, E-commerce, and EDI integrations. This role requires a hands-on manager who can lead a team of software engineers, foster their growth, and ensure alignment with business objectives. Why I Have Declined a Fully-Remote $7,150 Net/Month Offer.Recently, I was actively job hunting and got pretty far with a promising opportunity. I completed the technical task, passed the interviews, and received an offer from a well-known international company with a strong media presence and a quite ethical business model.The position was for a DevOps engineer. The terms were excellent: official B2B contract, fully remote work - I could work from anywhere, even a small village back home in Kazakhstan. They offered a three-week paid company bootcamp in Cyprus and a long-term collaboration. Some of their employees had been with the company for over 12 years - it sounded like a dream job.I had already arranged an early exit from my current work, started looking for tickets to Cyprus, and was mentally ready to sign the contract.But when the actual contract arrived, although it was generally fine, one detail immediately caught my attention: there was no liability limitation clause.For employees under standard labor law in almost any country, it is usually not an issue because labor laws protect employees against unlimited financial liability. But for B2B or contractor agreements, things are different - unless explicitly stated otherwise, the contractor can be held fully liable.As someone with significant DevOps experience, I know firsthand that mistakes can be costly. It might only take a few hours to accidentally cause damages worth several months of my salary. While I’ve never had a serious incident myself, I understand that no one is immune to risk - it’s part of the job.So, I politely asked to add a simple clause: to cap the liability to a maximum of three months' salary.The HR representative immediately refused, saying, "This is our standard contract. Everyone signs it, and so should you." They told me they’ve never had any lawsuits and insisted there was no need to change anything. Moreover, I was repeatedly told that literally no one in the whole company, including legal, HR, and the hiring manager, understands my concern and I should just sign the contract as it is. The hiring manager allegedly is also under the same contract, has caused damages ranging into hundreds of thousands of USD before, and "everything was fine."I spent a lot of time carefully explaining my concern - that it’s not about mistrust but about basic risk management - but they stuck to their position. Eventually, they gave me an ultimatum: sign it as-is, or walk away.I chose to walk away.I've been in this industry long enough to know: mistakes will happen eventually, and when they do, they can be very expensive. Signing a contract with unlimited personal liability would be like playing Russian roulette with my financial future. In my opinion it just wasn't worth it.

My Friday thought for today! “Hiring Indigenous talent isn’t just about being inclusive—it’s about empowering the future of work."As an Indigenous woman, I’ve often felt the weight of walking into interviews wondering if I’d be seen, heard, or truly considered. When I applied to Clear Seas I was nervous. I didn’t think I’d get the job—I didn’t tick every single box on the job posting.  But here I am 5 years later, loving and always learning in my role as Director of Indigenous Programs. Too often, Indigenous professionals are overlooked. Told we’re not “qualified” enough. Told we don’t quite “fit.” But here’s what I want to say to every employer out there: Indigenous people are more than survivors of colonization and residential schools—we are leaders.We bring with us generations of knowledge, a spirit of adaptability, and an openness to learning and growth. We are connectors. Listeners. Innovators. And when we apply for roles in your organization, we’re not just looking for a job—we’re offering *you* a chance to work *with us.*So, yes—hire Indigenous professionals. Not just because it’s good for reconciliation, or because it checks a box. Do it because we’re powerful. We’re forward-thinking. hashtag#IndigenousCareers hashtag#ReconciliationInAction hashtag#ICPP hashtag#OceanSector hashtag#IndigenousExcellence hashtag#ClearSeas hashtag#RepresentationMatters
